1.title: Consultation with Purpose
1.description: We begin with dialogue. Whether the commission is sacred, commemorative, or personal, we listen carefully because we seek clarity rather than assumption. Every symbol, proportion, and gesture is considered for meaning rather than just form. This first step ensures that the essence of the work is honored before a single mark is made.

2.title: Modeling the Vision
2.description: Once aligned, we translate the concept into physical reality through precise 3D modeling and clay prototyping. Clients review every detail, from posture to expression, until it feels complete. No stone is touched until the form is fully approved, and this is where the vision becomes visible and where trust is built.

3.title: Carving with Discipline
3.description: With the approved model confirmed, we engage our CNC system. Multi-axis machining allows us to execute complex geometries with millimetric precision because it protects the integrity of the approved design. This is not automation for speed but rather technology in service of fidelity.

4.title: Finishing by Hand
4.description: After the machine, the hands begin. Our master artisans refine surface, expression, and subtle presence with tools and intuition that have been honed over decades. No machine can interpret warmth or grace, and it is this stage where the piece becomes truly alive with softness, reverence, and soul.

5.title: Global Delivery with Integrity
5.description: Once complete, each piece is inspected and documented. It is then crated for international shipment using museum-grade standards. Installation guides, support, and care documentation ensure that the artwork arrives and endures exactly as intended.

religious-1.name: Enlightenment Buddha
religious-1.description:
Commissioned by a respected Thai monastery for their sister temple in the United States, this Enlightenment Buddha was sculpted to serve as the spiritual heart of Wat Nawamintararachutis in Taunton, Massachusetts — a temple built in honor of His Majesty King Rama IX. As Buddhism takes root abroad, this sacred figure offers a constant presence for those seeking stillness, prayer, and renewal.

The statue resides in the meditation hall on the second floor — a quiet, light-filled space designed for deep contemplation. Pilgrims and practitioners gather beneath this image not simply to observe it, but to be guided by it. Carved from fine Thassos white marble sourced from Greece, the stone was chosen for its crystal clarity and its capacity to reflect light with dignity. When sunlight moves through the room, the surface glows in silence — never imposing, always present.

The original artist appointed by the temple traveled from Thailand to our studio to oversee the final refinements. Working side-by-side with BMG's master-level artisans, every line, fold, and facial proportion was resolved with reverence. The final polish — full gloss across every surface — was applied with care to ensure purity, balance, and spiritual precision.

Today, the Buddha anchors the meditation hall as a still guardian. It does not draw attention; it centers it. With each seated gathering, it offers clarity not through words, but through form — carved once, present always.

religious-2.name: Chedi Phra Thad Phut Tha Phucha
religious-2.artTitle: Chedi Phra Thad Phut Tha Phucha – Wat Ratanawan
religious-2.description:
Commissioned by the Sangha of Wat Ratanawan under the leadership of Venerable Luang Por Nyanadhammo, this monumental stupa was created as a vessel of sacred remembrance. Named Chedi Phra Thad Phut Tha Phucha, it was constructed to enshrine holy relics of the Buddha and his disciples, standing not only as a physical landmark but as a beacon of merit and collective devotion.

The structure is the largest known granite stupa in the Buddhist tradition. The largest stone block used measured 2.5 x 1.2 x 8.8 meters and weighed 105 tons — quarried and lifted with two forklifts working in precise harmony. Every piece was shaped by CNC-guided wire saw and then finished by hand. Our team worked in close collaboration with the monks at every stage, with many of us choosing to temporarily ordain during installation — an act of respect and shared spiritual intention.

Once the granite structure was completed, the entire body was clad in gold-finished stainless steel — a material chosen for its lasting brilliance and purity of presence. During the opening ceremony, over 250 monks gathered in unison with thousands of lay practitioners. The atmosphere was one of stillness and significance, a shared recognition that this chedi would outlast all who stood before it.

Today, the stupa reflects not only light, but lineage — rising against the sky as a physical embodiment of devotion, community, and the noble path.

religious-3.name: Ganesh
religious-3.description:
This sculpture was commissioned by Mo Amena Pinit, who approached the work with a clear personal vision of Ganesh already formed. Rather than referencing an existing depiction, the intention was to give form to an image held internally — one defined by feeling, balance, and presence.

The sculpture developed through careful interpretation. Proportion, posture, and expression were shaped gradually, guided by her original intent and refined as the form emerged. The process remained focused on clarity and alignment, allowing the sculpture to take shape without excess or deviation.

The completed work stands as a spiritual piece shaped by personal belief, where an internal vision was translated into a lasting form and allowed to remain quietly present.

religious-4.name: Buddha Cover Jade
religious-4.description:
A sacred Buddha sculpture created to encase and protect precious jade relics. Carved from White Carrara marble, this piece serves as both a protective vessel and a devotional centerpiece.

The design honors traditional Buddhist iconography while providing a dignified enclosure for the sacred materials within. Every proportion was carefully considered to maintain spiritual authenticity and visual harmony.

religious-5.name: Wat Pa Phu Kon Buddha
religious-5.artTitle: Sacred Buddha – Wat Pa Phu Kon
religious-5.description:
Created for Wat Pa Phu Kon, this White Carrara marble Buddha embodies the serene presence that defines this renowned forest monastery. The sculpture was crafted with deep respect for the contemplative traditions of the temple.

Every detail was refined to support meditation and spiritual practice, with surfaces polished to reflect natural light in a way that enhances rather than distracts from the devotional atmosphere.

religious-6.name: Somdet Phra Wannarat
religious-6.description:
A commemorative sculpture honoring the revered Buddhist patriarch Somdet Phra Wannarat, created for Wat Bowonniwet Vihara — one of Thailand's most significant royal temples.

Carved from Black African granite, the piece captures the dignified presence of this important religious figure. The dark stone was selected for its ability to convey gravitas and permanence, befitting the legacy being honored.

religious-7.name: Pacific Hermitage Buddha
religious-7.description:
Created for Pacific Hermitage in Oregon, this Buddha sculpture brings the contemplative traditions of Theravada Buddhism to the Pacific Northwest. Carved from red sandstone, the piece connects to ancient sculptural traditions while serving a contemporary monastic community.

The warm tones of the sandstone complement the natural forest setting of the hermitage, creating a harmonious presence for meditation and spiritual practice.

religious-8.name: Wat Pa Phuritatta Buddha
religious-8.description:
A serene Buddha sculpture crafted from Super White marble for Wat Pa Phuritatta Pattipatharam. The pristine white stone was selected to embody purity and spiritual clarity.

The sculpture serves as a focal point for meditation and devotion, with every surface refined to support contemplative practice.

religious-9.name: Phra Khanthararat
religious-9.artTitle: พระคันธราช – Sacred Commission
religious-9.description:
A sacred sculpture commissioned by Sonlapratan, crafted from white stone to embody spiritual presence and devotional significance.

The piece was created with careful attention to traditional iconography and proportions, ensuring authenticity and spiritual resonance in the final work.

legacy-1.name: Grandfather Portrait
legacy-1.description:
This sculpture was created after the grandfather had already passed, making the work an act of careful reconstruction guided by memory rather than direct observation. With no opportunity for live sittings, the form was developed from hundreds of family photographs — studied to understand expressions, posture, and the quiet details that defined his presence.

The process required precision, restraint, and continual dialogue with the family. Each stage — from digital modeling to carving and hand-finishing — was reviewed and approved to ensure the sculpture remained faithful not only to physical likeness, but to character and legacy. White Carrara marble was selected for its ability to hold softness and dignity, allowing the final work to convey warmth without excess.

Rather than capturing a single moment, the sculpture embodies collective remembrance. Crafted with care and intention at every step, it stands as a lasting presence — where personal legacy is preserved through disciplined process, material integrity, and mastery-level craftsmanship.

legacy-2.name: Grandmother Portrait
legacy-2.description:
This sculpture was initiated while the grandmother was still alive, allowing the process to begin from direct presence rather than memory alone. A full scan was conducted to capture form and proportion, establishing the foundation of the work before carving commenced.

The project was intentionally paused before completion. After her passing, the sculpture was resumed, refined, and completed in time to be delivered for her funeral services. The process unfolded with sensitivity to both timing and execution, allowing the work to remain faithful to who she was, without urgency or excess.

legacy-3.name: Jade Memorial
legacy-3.description:
A sacred memorial piece crafted from Green Italy stone to honor and preserve the memory of a loved one. This intimate work was commissioned by Wuttipong Chaisang as a vessel for remembrance.

The green stone was selected for its connection to life and renewal, creating a piece that honors the past while offering comfort to those who remain.

architectural-1.name: Infinity Bridge Fountain
architectural-1.description:
Commissioned by a revered waterworks patron and his Feng Shui master, this sacred sculpture serves not only as a water feature but as a symbolic convergence of flow, continuity, and grounded prosperity.

A singular, oversized block of Thai granite — selected for both its geological resilience and harmonious grain — was sculpted into a continuous infinity loop to anchor the front court of the client's home. According to spiritual counsel, water was to pass through this form as a 'bridge of continuity,' ensuring wealth and energy would flow uninterrupted through the residence.

The form was resolved through multiple guided sessions with the patron and his spiritual advisor, each curve refined to exacting standards — down to a tolerance of 0.1 millimeters. This fidelity was achieved through a calibrated combination of CNC precision and artisan eye, ensuring that not a single gesture deviated from the original spiritual intent.

Final placement involved multi-tiered basin alignment to cradle the sculpture in concentric circles of water, echoing the continuous motion of the piece itself. Every line, polish, and plane was executed to instill presence without excess — a silent architecture of blessing and form.

architectural-2.name: Wat Sothorn Marble Restoration
architectural-2.artTitle: A Legacy Etched in Stone – Wat Sothorn
architectural-2.description:
For over two decades, the Grand Ubosot (main chapel) of Wat Sothorn Wararam Worawihan in Chachoengsao has stood as a testament not just to faith, but to a profound collaboration between spirit and artistry. This was not a mere construction project; it was a pilgrimage of dedication, culminating in a monument of national significance.

Around 26 years ago, in an endeavor supported by His Majesty the King, the esteemed leadership of the temple sought to adorn the exterior and interior walls of the new Ubosot. The vision was massive, requiring a material worthy of its spiritual gravity — a material whose legacy transcended eras.

The choice was made: Statuario marble, sourced exclusively from the very Italian quarries that yielded the masterpieces of Michelangelo.

This commitment to perfection necessitated a journey. A monk and the project consultant traveled with our team to the ancient quarries of Italy. This was a mission of reverence: to personally hand-select each raw block of Statuario, ensuring that every slab destined for Wat Sothorn held the luminosity, purity, and character required for a place of such sanctity.

The marble, already immortalized by the Renaissance masters, found its new purpose in Thailand. It now serves as the permanent skin of the Grand Ubosot, its cool, luminous white and subtle grey veining reflecting the quiet clarity of devotion.

architectural-3.name: Wat Arun Legacy Guardians
architectural-3.description:
At Wat Arun, one of Thailand's most iconic temples, stood a collection of Chinese stone guardians dating back over 200 years — lions, door sentinels, and noble figures placed to protect sacred thresholds. Time had softened their edges and fractured their forms. The task was not to repair, but to resurrect — to protect the artist's original intent and allow the legacy to live forward without interruption.

BMG approached this commission as a sacred responsibility. Using 3D scanning technology, we captured not only the broken fragments but the millimeter-precise soul of each figure. Every surface, curve, and texture was recorded in full fidelity. This raw data became the spiritual blueprint for renewal.

Each form was re-sculpted from green marble — a dense, enduring stone chosen for both longevity and surface character. Using a 5-axis CNC system, we translated the scan into exact material dimensions. Then, with the original artifacts laid side by side, our artisans refined every contour by hand. Where the machine delivered structure, the human hand restored presence.

From lions to Western-style gatekeepers, every element was matched — not copied, but continued. Each is now reborn not as a replica, but as an immutable extension of the original. This is not restoration. It is remembrance in form.

architectural-4.name: Wat Pa Dan Wiwek Monument
architectural-4.artTitle: Sacred Monument – Wat Pa Dan Wiwek
architectural-4.description:
A monumental work created for Wat Pa Dan Wiwek, combining Black African granite with Thai granite to create a structure of lasting significance.

The dual-stone approach was selected to achieve both visual impact and structural integrity, with the contrasting materials creating a dialogue between darkness and light that enhances the spiritual presence of the monument.
